sections.title: Match Your Money to the Best Home
sections.subtitle: Evaluate checking and savings options so fees stay low and features elevate your cash flow

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: How different account types support spending, saving, and long-term goals
Which fee structures and requirements to watch for before opening an account
Feature checklists for digital-first banks vs. credit unions and community banks
A decision matrix you can reuse whenever your banking needs change

sections.title: Banking as Infrastructure
sections.content: The right bank account removes friction from daily money management. Checking handles transactions, savings protects short-term goals, and specialized accounts (cash management, HSAs, business accounts) add targeted utility. Instead of defaulting to the bank closest to home, analyze how you use money today and which tools will support tomorrow's goals.

points.title: Monthly Fees & Minimums
points.description: Aim for zero or easily waived fees. Know the balance or activity required to keep the account free.

points.title: Access & Convenience
points.description: Consider ATM networks, branch proximity, mobile deposit limits, and customer support hours.

points.title: Technology Stack
points.description: Budgeting integrations, bill pay, push notifications, and virtual cards can automate better habits.

points.title: Safety & Insurance
points.description: FDIC/NCUA coverage up to $250,000 per depositor per ownership category protects deposits.

sections.title: One Size? No Thanks
sections.content: Most people benefit from using two institutions: a primary checking account for bills and an online high-yield savings account for goals.

sections.title: Big Bank vs. Digital Bank vs. Credit Union
sections.content: Big banks offer vast ATM networks and in-person service but often low savings rates. Digital banks deliver strong yields and lower fees, yet cash deposits can be tricky. Credit unions provide community focus and competitive loan rates. Compare each against your priorities—there is no universal best, only the best fit.

sections.title: Decision Matrix Walkthrough
sections.content: Create a 1-5 scoring matrix covering fees, yields, features, access, and customer reviews. Weight categories based on your lifestyle (e.g., frequent travelers prioritize ATM access). Score three candidate institutions, tally totals, and document why your chosen bank wins. Repeat annually or whenever your needs evolve.

sections.title: Account Selection Sprint
steps: List the accounts you currently hold, including balances and fees
Identify pain points (e.g., low yield, high fees, clunky app)
Pick three new institutions to evaluate using the lesson matrix
Score each institution and choose a primary + secondary option
Schedule account opening and fund transfers, then set a 6-month review reminder

sections.title: Use Ally/SoFi/Local Combo
sections.content: Pair a feature-rich online bank with a nearby credit union. You get digital automation plus an in-person fallback when you need cashier’s checks or immediate assistance.
